description: A flexible tag template that allows you to inject custom HTML, JavaScript, or CSS code into your website. This is the most versatile tag type for implementing custom tracking, widgets, or any third-party code snippets that don't have a dedicated template.

when_to_use: When you need to add custom JavaScript tracking code
For implementing third-party widgets or scripts not covered by other templates
When adding custom HTML elements or CSS styles
When integrating with APIs or services that require custom code
common_use_cases: Heatmap or user behavior tracking tools

create_tag.description: Create a new tag using this template

app_id.description: The Piwik PRO app ID where you want to create the tag

attributes.description: Tag attributes object containing all tag configuration

triggers.description: Comma-separated list of trigger UUIDs to attach to this tag
notes: If not provided or empty, tag will be created without triggers
Triggers determine when and under what conditions the tag fires
You can attach triggers later using update_tag or manage them separately

update_tag.description: Update an existing tag - only editable fields can be modified

app_id.description: The Piwik PRO app ID containing the tag

tag_id.description: The UUID of the tag to update

attributes.description: Tag attributes object containing fields to update (only editable fields will be processed)

triggers.description: Comma-separated list of trigger UUIDs to replace current triggers
notes: If not provided, existing triggers remain unchanged
If provided (even empty string), replaces ALL existing triggers
Use empty string to remove all triggers from the tag

name.description: A descriptive name for your tag (will be visible in Tag Manager interface)

template.description: Must always be 'custom_tag' for this template
template.edit_note: ‚ö†Ô∏è Cannot be changed after tag creation

code.description: The actual HTML, JavaScript, or CSS code to be injected
best_practices: Use proper HTML structure for HTML content
Keep code as lightweight as possible
Use async/defer attributes for external scripts when appropriate

consent_type.description: Defines what type of user consent is required before this tag fires

options.not_require_consent: Tag doesn't require any consent (e.g., essential functionality)
options.ab_testing_and_personalization: Requires consent for A/B testing and personalization
options.user_feedback: Requires consent for user feedback collection

consent_type.ai_recommendation: Use 'not_require_consent' for essential functionality, 'analytics' for tracking code, 'marketing_automation' for marketing scripts

is_active.description: Whether the tag is active and should fire
is_active.recommendation: Usually leave as true unless you want to temporarily disable the tag

disable_in_debug_mode.description: Whether to disable this tag when Tag Manager is in debug mode
disable_in_debug_mode.recommendation: Set to true for production-only tags that shouldn't fire during testing

document_write.description: Whether this tag uses JavaScript's deprecated document.write() method
document_write.recommendation: Only set to true if you're certain your code uses document.write (not recommended for modern code)

priority.description: Firing order priority (higher numbers fire earlier)
priority.recommendation: Use higher numbers for tags that need to fire before others (e.g., consent managers)

respect_visitors_privacy.description: Whether to respect visitor privacy settings (DNT header, opt-out)
respect_visitors_privacy.recommendation: Keep as true to respect user privacy preferences

scheduler.description: Optional scheduling to control when the tag fires based on date/time

date_ranges.description: Array of date range objects defining when tag should be active

times_of_day.description: Array of time range objects defining daily active hours

trigger_management.overview: Triggers define when and under what conditions your custom tag will fire. Without triggers, a tag won't execute.
trigger_types: page_view - Fires when a page loads
click - Fires when user clicks on specific elements
form_submission - Fires when forms are submitted
scroll_depth - Fires when user scrolls to certain depth
custom_event - Fires on custom JavaScript events
timer - Fires after specified time intervals
element_visibility - Fires when elements become visible

workflow.step_1: Use piwik_list_triggers(app_id) to see available triggers
workflow.step_2: Use piwik_get_trigger(app_id, trigger_id) to understand trigger conditions
workflow.step_3: Include trigger UUIDs in the triggers parameter when creating tag
workflow.step_4: Use piwik_get_tag_triggers(app_id, tag_id) to verify trigger attachments

trigger_discovery_tools: piwik_list_triggers(app_id) - List all available triggers in the app
piwik_get_trigger(app_id, trigger_id) - Get details about a specific trigger
piwik_create_trigger(app_id, attributes) - Create new triggers if needed
piwik_get_tag_triggers(app_id, tag_id) - See which triggers are attached to a tag
piwik_get_trigger_tags(app_id, trigger_id) - See which tags use a specific trigger
best_practices: Always attach at least one trigger, otherwise the tag won't fire
Use page_view triggers for tags that should run on every page load
Use click triggers for tags that should fire on user interactions
Test trigger conditions before attaching to important tags
Consider trigger priority and order for complex setups

basic_custom_script.description: Simple custom JavaScript tracking (without triggers - won't fire)

attributes.name: Custom Analytics Event
attributes.code:
<script>
  // Send custom event to analytics
  if (typeof gtag !== 'undefined') {
    gtag('event', 'custom_interaction', {
      'event_category': 'engagement',
      'event_label': 'custom_tag_fired'
    });
  }
</script>

basic_custom_script.note: ‚ö†Ô∏è This tag won't fire without triggers attached. See examples below for proper trigger usage.

custom_script_with_page_view_trigger.description: Custom JavaScript that fires on every page load

attributes.name: Custom Analytics Event
attributes.code:
<script>
  // Send custom event to analytics
  if (typeof gtag !== 'undefined') {
    gtag('event', 'page_view_custom', {
      'event_category': 'engagement',
      'event_label': 'custom_tag_fired',
      'page_url': window.location.href
    });
  }
</script>

custom_script_with_page_view_trigger.prerequisite: Requires a page view trigger. Use piwik_list_triggers() to find available triggers.

third_party_widget.description: Loading a third-party widget with multiple triggers

attributes.name: Chat Widget
attributes.code:
<script>
  (function() {
    var script = document.createElement('script');
    script.src = 'https://widget.example.com/chat.js';
    script.async = true;
    document.head.appendChild(script);
  })();
</script>

third_party_widget.explanation: This widget will load on both page view and DOM ready events, ensuring it works in various scenarios.

click_triggered_tag.description: Custom tag that fires when user clicks specific elements

attributes.name: Button Click Tracker
attributes.code:
<script>
  // Track button clicks
  console.log('Button clicked:', event.target.textContent);
  if (typeof gtag !== 'undefined') {
    gtag('event', 'button_click', {
      'event_category': 'engagement',
      'event_label': event.target.textContent || 'unknown_button'
    });
  }
</script>

click_triggered_tag.prerequisite: Requires a click trigger configured for button elements. Use piwik_create_trigger() to create one if needed.

scheduled_campaign.description: Custom tag that only fires during a specific campaign period

scheduled_campaign.note: Scheduled tags still need triggers to fire. The scheduler adds additional time-based conditions.

complete_workflow_example.description: Complete example showing trigger discovery and tag creation

tag_not_firing: Verify triggers are attached: Use piwik_get_tag_triggers(app_id, tag_id)
Check trigger conditions: Use piwik_get_trigger(app_id, trigger_id)
Ensure triggers are active: Check trigger is_active status
Test trigger conditions manually in browser
Check if tag consent requirements are met
common_trigger_issues: No triggers attached - tag will never fire
Trigger conditions don't match website behavior
Multiple conflicting triggers causing unexpected behavior
Trigger timing issues (e.g., firing before required elements load)

tag_management: piwik_update_tag(app_id, tag_id, attributes, triggers) - Update tag and its triggers
piwik_get_tag(app_id, tag_id) - Get complete tag information

common_mistakes: Forgetting to wrap JavaScript code in <script> tags
Not considering consent requirements for tracking code
Including heavy/blocking code without proper async loading
Not testing the code before creating the tag
Using document.write in modern code (set document_write: true if you must)
Creating tags without triggers - they won't fire!
Not understanding trigger conditions before attaching them
Forgetting to verify trigger attachments after tag creation

tag_not_firing: üî• MOST COMMON: Check if triggers are attached using piwik_get_tag_triggers()
Verify triggers are active and conditions are met
Check if tag is active (is_active: true)
Test trigger conditions manually in browser
code_not_working: Verify external script URLs are accessible
Ensure tag is firing first (check triggers)

field_mutability_guide.description: Understanding field editability after tag creation

editable.description: ‚úÖ Can be updated anytime after creation
editable.note: These fields can be safely modified through update_tag operations

create-only.description: ‚ö†Ô∏è Set during creation, immutable after creation
create-only.note: These fields are ignored in update operations and cannot be changed once the tag is created

read-only.note: These fields are managed by the API and automatically filtered out from update requests

update_workflow.description: Best practices for updating custom tags
steps: 1. Use piwik_get_tag() to see current field values and their mutability status
2. Only include editable fields in your update_tag attributes object
3. API automatically filters out create-only and read-only fields
4. Use piwik_get_tag_triggers() to manage trigger relationships separately if needed
